title: Prove norm_dualDistribL_tprod_le: norm bound on pure dual tensors
description:
Prove the norm bound for dualDistribL applied to pure tensors of dual elements.

Statement:
  theorem norm_dualDistribL_tprod_le (f : Œ† i, NormedSpace.StrongDual ùïú (E i)) :
    ‚ÄñdualDistribL (‚®Ç‚Çú[ùïú] i, f i)‚Äñ ‚â§ ‚àè i, ‚Äñf i‚Äñ

This bound is crucial for the lower bound in the main theorem. It says the continuous linear functional obtained by tensoring duals has operator norm at most the product of the individual dual norms.

Proof strategy:
- dualDistribL(‚®Ç f_i) is a continuous linear functional on ‚®Ç[ùïú] i, E i
- Its operator norm is sup over ‚ÄñdualDistribL(‚®Ç f_i)(x)‚Äñ / ‚Äñx‚Äñ
- On pure tensors: |‚àè f_i(m_i)| ‚â§ ‚àè ‚Äñf_i‚Äñ ¬∑ ‚àè ‚Äñm_i‚Äñ ‚â§ (‚àè ‚Äñf_i‚Äñ) ¬∑ projectiveSeminorm(‚®Ç m_i)
- Extend to all x by density/linearity + projective seminorm definition

Alternatively: this may follow from the fact that dualDistribL is constructed via mapL/liftEquiv whose norm is controlled.

Acceptance: theorem proven without sorry.

title: Create WithBidual.lean: prove lower bound using norming sequences + dualDistribL
description:
Create ProjSeminorm/WithBidual.lean and prove the core lower bound for the projective seminorm on pure tensors, assuming the bidual isometry hypothesis.

Statement:
  theorem projectiveSeminorm_tprod_of_bidual_iso
    (m : Œ† i, E i)
    (h_bidual : ‚àÄ i, ‚ÄñinclusionInDoubleDual ùïú _ (m i)‚Äñ = ‚Äñm i‚Äñ) :
    projectiveSeminorm (‚®Ç‚Çú[ùïú] i, m i) = ‚àè i, ‚Äñm i‚Äñ

Proof structure:
1. apply le_antisymm (projectiveSeminorm_tprod_le m) for upper bound (already in mathlib)
2. For lower bound, need: ‚àè i, ‚Äñm i‚Äñ ‚â§ projectiveSeminorm (‚®Ç‚Çú[ùïú] i, m i)

Lower bound proof:
- For each i, h_bidual gives ‚ÄñinclusionInDoubleDual(m_i)‚Äñ = ‚Äñm_i‚Äñ
- This means sup_{‚Äñf_i‚Äñ‚â§1} |f_i(m_i)| = ‚Äñm_i‚Äñ
- Use exists_norming_sequence (from Step 2) at each index i to get g_i^(n) in E_i* with ‚Äñg_i^(n)(m_i)‚Äñ / ‚Äñg_i^(n)‚Äñ ‚Üí ‚Äñm_i‚Äñ
- For any representation ‚®Ç m_i = ‚àë_j ‚®Ç v_j, evaluate dualDistribL(‚®Ç g_i^(n) / ‚Äñg_i^(n)‚Äñ):
  |‚àè_i g_i^(n)(m_i)/‚Äñg_i^(n)‚Äñ| = |dualDistribL(‚®Ç gÃÉ_i^(n))(‚®Ç m_i)|
    ‚â§ ‚ÄñdualDistribL(‚®Ç gÃÉ_i^(n))‚Äñ ¬∑ projectiveSeminorm(‚®Ç m_i)
    ‚â§ (‚àè ‚ÄñgÃÉ_i^(n)‚Äñ) ¬∑ projectiveSeminorm(‚®Ç m_i)
    ‚â§ 1 ¬∑ projectiveSeminorm(‚®Ç m_i)     [since ‚ÄñgÃÉ_i^(n)‚Äñ ‚â§ 1]
- Taking n ‚Üí ‚àû: ‚àè ‚Äñm_i‚Äñ ‚â§ projectiveSeminorm(‚®Ç m_i)

Key Lean machinery:
- Tendsto.prod (product of convergent sequences converges to product)
- le_of_tendsto (limit of lower bounds is a lower bound)
- norm_dualDistribL_tprod_le (from Step 3)
- exists_norming_sequence (from Step 2)

This is the mathematical heart of the project.

title: Create DirectApproach.lean: formalize the algebraic decomposition for binary tensors
description:
Create ProjSeminorm/DirectApproach.lean to formalize the direct algebraic approach to proving the lower bound without duality.

This file documents a proof ATTEMPT that ultimately fails, which is valuable for understanding why h_bidual seems necessary.

The binary tensor product case (E ‚äó F, pure tensor v ‚äó w = ‚àë v_j ‚äó w_j):

Step-by-step algebraic argument:
1. Choose a maximal linearly independent subset of {w_j}. Say w_1,...,w_s are independent.
2. Write dependent w_j = ‚àë_k a_{jk} w_k for j > s.
3. Combine: ‚àë v_j ‚äó w_j = ‚àë_k u_k ‚äó w_k where u_k = v_k + ‚àë_{j>s} a_{jk} v_j
4. Since w_1,...,w_s independent and v ‚äó w = ‚àë u_k ‚äó w_k: we get w = ‚àë c_k w_k and u_k = c_k v
5. So ‚Äñu_k‚Äñ = |c_k| ¬∑ ‚Äñv‚Äñ, and ‚àë ‚Äñu_k‚Äñ ¬∑ ‚Äñw_k‚Äñ = ‚Äñv‚Äñ ¬∑ ‚àë |c_k| ¬∑ ‚Äñw_k‚Äñ ‚â• ‚Äñv‚Äñ ¬∑ ‚Äñw‚Äñ

THE OBSTRUCTION: Step 3‚Üí5 works for the REDUCED representation (independent w_k), but reducing changes the cost. The original cost ‚àë ‚Äñv_j‚Äñ ¬∑ ‚Äñw_j‚Äñ is NOT necessarily ‚â• the reduced cost ‚àë ‚Äñu_k‚Äñ ¬∑ ‚Äñw_k‚Äñ. The triangle inequality goes the wrong way.

Key mathlib facts needed:
- TensorProduct.eq_zero_of_linearIndependent (or PiTensorProduct analog)
- LinearIndependent API
- The algebraic fact: in E ‚äó F, ‚àë e_j ‚äó f_j = 0 with f_j independent ‚üπ e_j = 0

Formalize as much as possible. The placeholder theorem can be proved with trivial/True.

Acceptance: file compiles, obstruction clearly documented in comments.

title: Document wrong-direction triangle inequality obstruction in DirectApproach.lean
description:
Add detailed documentation to DirectApproach.lean explaining exactly why the direct algebraic approach fails.

The chain of inequalities:
  ‚Äñv‚Äñ ¬∑ ‚Äñw‚Äñ = ‚Äñv‚Äñ ¬∑ ‚Äñ‚àë c_k w_k‚Äñ
             ‚â§ ‚Äñv‚Äñ ¬∑ ‚àë |c_k| ¬∑ ‚Äñw_k‚Äñ        [triangle on w ‚Äî correct direction]
             ‚â§ ‚àë_k (‚àë_j |a_{jk}| ¬∑ ‚Äñv_j‚Äñ) ¬∑ ‚Äñw_k‚Äñ   [from u_k = c_k v bound]
             = ‚àë_j ‚Äñv_j‚Äñ ¬∑ (‚àë_k |a_{jk}| ¬∑ ‚Äñw_k‚Äñ)   [swap sums]

We want this ‚â§ ‚àë_j ‚Äñv_j‚Äñ ¬∑ ‚Äñw_j‚Äñ, but:
  ‚àë_k |a_{jk}| ¬∑ ‚Äñw_k‚Äñ ‚â• ‚Äñ‚àë_k a_{jk} w_k‚Äñ = ‚Äñw_j‚Äñ

So the intermediate quantity is BIGGER than both sides. We proved A ‚â§ B and B ‚â• C but need A ‚â§ C.

Special cases where it DOES work:
- Ultrametric (non-archimedean): triangle ‚âà equality with d-orthogonal bases, defect ‚Üí 0
- Archimedean: triangle inequality can be arbitrarily lossy, proof is stuck

This analysis explains why h_bidual (enabling the duality approach) is the natural path.

Acceptance: clear mathematical documentation in the Lean file as module docstring and inline comments.

title: Create Counterexample.lean: investigate counterexamples for general fields
description:
Create ProjSeminorm/Counterexample.lean documenting the counterexample investigation for non-archimedean fields.

Key points to document and (where possible) formalize:

1. FINITE-DIMENSIONAL IMPOSSIBILITY: No counterexample in finite dimensions over any field. Reason: Hahn-Banach holds for finite-dimensional subspaces, so the bidual embedding is always isometric in finite dimensions. The h_bidual hypothesis is automatically satisfied.

2. INFINITE-DIMENSIONAL CANDIDATES over ‚Ñö_p:
   - There exist Banach spaces over ‚Ñö_p with trivial dual (E* = {0})
   - Example: completion of c‚ÇÄ‚ÇÄ(‚Ñï, ‚Ñö_p) under ‚Äñ(a_n)‚Äñ = (‚àë |a_n|_p^{1/2})¬≤
   - If E* = {0}, then ‚Äñx‚Äñ_bidual = 0 for all x, so the duality lower bound gives 0
   - Question: can 'spreading out' a pure tensor into a sum actually reduce cost?

3. NAIVE ATTEMPTS ALL FAIL:
   - e‚ÇÅ ‚äó e‚ÇÅ = (e‚ÇÅ + Œµe‚ÇÇ) ‚äó e‚ÇÅ - Œµe‚ÇÇ ‚äó e‚ÇÅ ‚Üí cost = 1 + 2Œµ > 1
   - Polarization-type decompositions also increase cost
   - No known representation achieves cost < ‚Äñv‚Äñ ¬∑ ‚Äñw‚Äñ

4. KEY INSIGHT: The projective norm infimum is purely metric-algebraic. Having poor dual doesn't directly help minimize the infimum ‚Äî it only removes the duality-based PROOF of the lower bound, not the lower bound itself.

This file may remain as documentation only (no executable proofs), which is still valuable.

Acceptance: comprehensive mathematical documentation in the Lean file. File compiles.

title: Prove projectiveSeminorm_field_tprod: scalar tensor norm equals product of absolute values
description:
Prove that the projective seminorm on a pure tensor of field elements equals the product of their norms.

Statement:
  theorem projectiveSeminorm_field_tprod (c : Œπ ‚Üí ùïú) :
    projectiveSeminorm (‚®Ç‚Çú[ùïú] i, c i) = ‚àè i, ‚Äñc i‚Äñ

This is for the special case E i = ùïú for all i, i.e., ‚®Ç[ùïú] i, ùïú.

Proof strategy:
- Upper bound: immediate from projectiveSeminorm_tprod_le (already in mathlib)
- Lower bound: use constantBaseRingEquiv : (‚®Ç[ùïú] i, ùïú) ‚âÉ‚Çê[ùïú] ùïú to identify the tensor product with ùïú itself. Under this isomorphism, ‚®Ç‚Çú c_i maps to ‚àè c_i. The projective seminorm must be ‚â• the absolute value of ‚àè c_i = ‚àè |c_i| because any continuous functional evaluation gives a lower bound.

Alternatively: use the fact that for 1-dimensional spaces, the projective and injective norms coincide, and both equal the product norm.

title: Define dualDistribL as a continuous linear map
description:
Define the continuous version of the algebraic dualDistrib map.

Statement:
  noncomputable def dualDistribL :
    (‚®Ç[ùïú] i, NormedSpace.StrongDual ùïú (E i)) ‚ÜíL[ùïú]
    NormedSpace.StrongDual ùïú (‚®Ç[ùïú] i, E i)

The algebraic dualDistrib (from Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.PiTensorProduct.Dual) is:
  dualDistrib : (‚®Ç[R] i, Dual R (M i)) ‚Üí‚Çó[R] Dual R (‚®Ç[R] i, M i)

To get a continuous version, we need to:
1. Show dualDistrib is continuous with respect to the projective seminorm on the domain and the operator norm on the codomain
2. Lift to a ContinuousLinearMap (‚ÜíL[ùïú])

Strategy options:
- Use mapL (continuous functorial map) composed with constantBaseRingEquiv
- Directly show boundedness: ‚ÄñdualDistrib(x)‚Äñ ‚â§ C ¬∑ projectiveSeminorm(x) for some C
- Use PiTensorProduct.liftEquiv (the universal property of the injective seminorm)

The domain ‚®Ç[ùïú] i, Dual ùïú (E i) has its own seminorm instance (using injectiveSeminorm). The codomain Dual ùïú (‚®Ç[ùïú] i, E i) has the operator norm.

Acceptance: definition compiles and basic type-checking passes.
